title: Charge conservation
summary: In physics, charge conservation is the principle that the total electric charge in an isolated system never changes.[1]  The net quantity of electric charge, the amount of positive charge minus the amount of negative charge in the universe, is always conserved.   Charge conservation, considered as a physical conservation law, implies that the change in the amount of electric charge in any volume of space is exactly equal to the amount of charge flowing into the volume minus the amount of charge flowing out of the volume.
